title: Advanced Polynomial Identities (Newton, Vieta, Symmetry)
content:
Overview

This topic connects Vieta's formulas, Newton's sums, and symmetric polynomials for contest-level problem solving.

Vieta's Formulas

If P(x)=x^n+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdots+a_0 has roots r_1,\dots,r_n, then sums and products of roots are expressed via coefficients.

import sympy as sp
x=sp.symbols('x')
P = x**3 - 6*x**2 + 11*x - 6  # roots 1,2,3
r = sp.nroots(P)
S1 = sum(r)
S2 = sum(r[i]*r[j] for i in range(3) for j in range(i+1,3))
S3 = r[0]*r[1]*r[2]
print(round(S1.real,5), round(S2.real,5), round(S3.real,5))

Newton's Sums

Use power sums p_k=\sum r_i^k to connect to coefficients a_i. Helpful to find r_1^k+\cdots+r_n^k quickly.

# Newton's sums example for P(x)=x^3-6x^2+11x-6
# p1 = 6, p2 = 14, p3 = 36 for roots 1,2,3

Hard Problem

Let P(x)=x^3-3x+1 with roots r,s,t. Compute r^5+s^5+t^5 without approximating roots.

Solution Sketch

Use recurrence from x^3=3x-1 to reduce x^5 to lower powers; or set up Newton's sums with a_2=0,a_1=-3,a_0=1.
